The oligomerization of light olefins, such as isopentene, is crucial for producing valuable products like industrial chemicals in the petrochemical industry; however, developing efficient and stable catalysts remains challenging. In this study, we synthesized a sulfonated porous organic polymer, HSO3-POP-TB, via Friedel-Crafts alkylation using 1, 3, 5-triphenylbenzene (TB) and 4, 4’-dichloromethylbiphenyl (BB), followed by chlorosulfonic acid (HSO3Cl) sulfonation. The strong acidity and unique micro-/mesoporous structure of HSO₃-POP-TB are key to achieving high isopentene conversion and excellent dimer selectivity. Optimized HSO3-POP-TB demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance, with an isopentene conversion rate of 81.7 % and 95.0 % selectivity for the dimer product at 70 °C, surpassing conventional solid acid catalysts. Additionally, HSO3-POP-TB exhibited remarkable thermal stability and acid resistance, maintaining high activity over five reaction cycles without significant efficiency loss. These results highlight the potential of HSO3-POP-TB as a promising catalyst for the efficient and sustainable conversion of light olefins into valuable chemicals, addressing economic and environmental concerns. Graphical Abstract Keywords Catalyst Isopentene Oligomerization Porous organic polymer Sulfonation Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction Light olefins (C4-C6) are significant by-products of refinery processes and catalytic cracking operations [1–4] . Despite their low inherent value, these hydrocarbons can be transformed into value-added products through catalytic oligomerization and alkylation. These processes yield essential commodities such as high-octane gasoline, diesel, lubricants, and a variety of fine chemicals [5–7] . Therefore, exploring effective catalytic technologies to enhance the conversion efficiency and product selectivity of light olefins is a crucial research direction in the petrochemical industry. Oligomerization reactions typically require efficient acid catalysts to accelerate reaction rates and improve product selectivity [8–12]. Conventional solid acid catalysts, including cation exchange resins, solid phosphoric acid, zeolites, and metal oxides, have been used to meet the demands of oligomerization reactions to some extent [13–16]. However, they exhibit significant limitations. Cation exchange resins generally suffer from low surface area and limited cycle life and poor stability; solid phosphoric acid lacks a well-defined pore structure, resulting in uneven distribution of active sites, which affects catalytic activity and selectivity; and zeolites, with their small pore sizes, require harsh reaction conditions, such as high temperature and pressure, leading to relatively high synthesis costs. Additionally, these traditional catalysts often fail to provide the necessary high selectivity and activity required for modern chemical processes [17,18]. Porous Organic Polymers (POPs), as a new class of high molecular porous materials, exhibit unique micro- or mesoporous structures, high surface areas, and excellent physicochemical stability [19]. These characteristics make them promising candidates for applications in gas separation, storage, and heterogeneous catalysis. POPs are constructed from organic building blocks linked by covalent bonds, forming a network with high porosity and tunable pore sizes [20,21]. This feature positions them as potential catalysts for reactions involving larger molecules, such as the dimerization of isopentene. Due to the presence of branched chains, isopentene dimers typically exceed 2 nm in molecular size [22–24]. In contrast, conventional solid acid catalysts face challenges: zeolites often have pore sizes less than 1 nm, solid phosphoric acid lacks organized pores, and cation exchange resins have either oversized or non-uniform pores, which can significantly hinder the efficiency and selectivity of catalytic reactions. To further enhance the acidic catalytic performance of POPs, sulfonation is an effective strategy. By introducing sulfonic acid groups, sulfonated POPs not only gain strong acidity but also retain their stable pore structures and high surface areas, making them suitable for the oligomerization of light olefins [25,26]. Although there have been advancements in the application of POPs in heterogeneous catalysis, studies on enhancing isopentene conversion and dimer selectivity through tailored pore design and sulfonation of POPs are still limited [27–29]. In this work, we successfully synthesized a highly acidic porous organic catalyst, HSO3-POP-TB, by chlorosulfonic acid (HSO3Cl) treatment of POP-TB, and applied it to the dimerization of isopentene (C5). The experimental results demonstrated that HSO3-POP-TB retained favorable pore structure and stability after sulfonation. Under the conditions of 70 °C, HSO3-POP-TB efficiently catalyzed isopentene dimerization, achieving a conversion rate of 81.7 % and a selectivity of 95.0 % for the dimer product (C10). Compared to traditional solid acid catalysts such as sulfonic resin DA-330, zeolite Beta, ITQ-1, and H3PW12O40/MCM-41, HSO3-POP-TB exhibited superior catalytic performance. Moreover, HSO3-POP-TB maintained excellent catalytic activity after multiple cycles without any treatment, demonstrating outstanding stability and reusability potential. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of porous organic polymer POP-TB The synthesis route of POP-TB was outlined in Fig. 1 [30]. In a 250 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, 2.53 g (0.01 mol) of 4, 4’-dichloromethylbiphenyl (BB) and 1.54 g (0.005 mol) of 1, 3, 5-triphenylbenzene (TRB) were dissolved in 200 mL of dichloromethane. The solution was stirred until fully dissolved, followed by the rapid addition of 2.0 g (0.015 mol) of anhydrous aluminum chloride (AlCl3) powder. The reaction mixture was maintained at 40 °C and stirred continuously for 120 h. After completion, the reaction mixture was filtered under reduced pressure, and the obtained solid was washed with 200 mL of 5 % dilute hydrochloric (HCl) acid using ultrasonic agitation for 30 min. The solid was then filtered again and washed extensively with deionized water to remove residual acid and impurities. Finally, the material was dried under vacuum to yield 4.0 g of POP-TB. 2.2 Synthesis of sulfonated porous organic polymer HSO3-POP-TB Based on the synthetic route outlined in Fig. 1. 1.0 g of the precursor POP-TB and 20 mL of tetrachloroethane (C2H2Cl4) were placed in a 100 mL round-bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer, a gas absorption setup, and a nitrogen (N2) protection system. At room temperature, 7.0 g of HSO3Cl was slowly added dropwise to the mixture. After the addition was complete, the reaction temperature was gradually raised to 140 °C and maintained for 24 h. Upon completion of the reaction, the mixture was cooled to room temperature. The solid product was separated by filtration, extensively washed with deionized water, and then dried under vacuum to yield the sulfonated polymer HSO3-POP-TB. 2.3 Characterization FT-IR were characterized using a Thermo Fisher Scientific IS50 FT-IR spectrometer. The samples were ground with KBr at a ratio of 1:100 and pressed into pellets. The FT-IR spectra were recorded over a range from 400 to 4000 cm−1. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained using a Rigaku D/Max 2500PC X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ= 0.154 nm). The samples were placed on a glass substrate, and measurements were conducted over a 2θ range from 2.0 to 80.0°. Thermal stability was assessed using a PerkinElmer STA6000 thermogravimetric analyzer. The samples were tested under a N2 atmosphere, with the temperature ramping from 40 to 850 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The surface area and pore characteristics were evaluated using a Micromeritics ASAP2020 automatic physisorption analyzer. Measurements were performed at 77 K using a N2 adsorption-desorption techniques. All samples were pre-dried at 120 °C for a minimum of 2 h. The morphology of the samples was examined using a Zeiss SUPRA55 scanning electron microscope. The elemental composition of the samples was determined using a GBC 932Plus multi-element analyzer. 2.4 Dimerization of isopentene Before use, the HSO3-POP-TB catalyst was dried at 120 °C for 2 h in an oven at atmospheric pressure. The dried catalyst powder was then added to a 100 mL reaction vessel equipped with a magnetic stirrer, gas absorption setup, and N2 protection system. Under ice-bath conditions, 2 mL of isopentene was added to the vessel, which was then immediately sealed. The reaction vessel was purged three times with N2 to remove any air and then pressurized with N2 to the set pressure. The reaction was conducted under controlled temperature and pressure for a specified time. After the reaction, the vessel was cooled to room temperature and further cooled to below 10 °C using an ice bath. The reaction mixture was quickly filtered through a 2 μm filter membrane into a collection bottle and stored in a sealed container in a refrigerator. The products were analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS) to identify and quantify the components. During these reactions, products with the same number of carbon atoms are considered to have identical response factors in chromatographic analysis, simplifying the quantification of the products. The SP-6890 gas chromatograph was used with a 0.4 μL sample injection. The temperature program started at 50 °C for 3 min, then increased to 100 °C at 3 °C/min and held for 2 min. Finally, it was ramped to 220 °C at 25 °C/min and held for 3 min. The detector and injector temperatures were both set at 250 °C. By adjusting the temperature ramping program, different products, including dimer, trimer, and other cracking products, were separated and identified. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Optimization of process conditions for sulfonated POP-TB Under conditions of excess HSO3Cl, we systematically optimized the sulfonation of POP-TB to enhance its catalytic performance in the dimerization of isopentene by adjusting reaction temperature and time. Initial experiments revealed that the un-sulfonated POP-TB catalyst exhibited no activity in the oligomerization of C5 olefins, indicating the absence of necessary acidic sites for catalysis. In contrast, as illustrated in Fig. 2 A, sulfonated POP-TB demonstrated significant catalytic activity, effectively promoting the conversion of C5 olefins. At a reaction temperature of 140 °C, the conversion of C5 initially increased with the extension of sulfonation time from 12 to 24 h, attributable to the progressive increase in the number of sulfonic acid groups and active sites on POP-TB. However, further extending the sulfonation time to 30 h led to a marked decrease in conversion, primarily due to the partial collapse of the POP-TB structure under prolonged strong acid treatment. Notably, across all sulfonation conditions, the selectivity for the dimer product, C10, consistently exceeded 90 %. This high selectivity underscores the suitability of the POP-TB pore structure for facilitating rapid diffusion of reactants and products and favoring the formation of dimer products. In Fig. 2 B, we fixed the sulfonation time at 24 h and explored the effect of sulfonation temperature on the catalytic performance of HSO3-POP-TB for C5 oligomerization. The results show that as the temperature varied from 80 to 200 °C, the conversion of C5, as well as the selectivity and yield of C10, initially increased rapidly and then declined gradually. At lower temperatures, increasing the temperature enhanced the degree of sulfonation and the amount of sulfonic acid groups attached to POP-TB. However, excessive temperatures led to the collapse of the POP-TB framework, diminishing catalytic performance. In summary, a sulfonation temperature of 140 °C and a duration of 24 h were identified as the optimal conditions. Therefore, the subsequent material characterization was conducted under these specified conditions. 3.2 Catalyst characterization The pristine POP-TB was synthesized via Friedel-Crafts alkylation using 1, 3, 5-triphenylbenzene (TB) and 4, 4’-dichloromethylbiphenyl (BB) as precursors and characterized for its high surface area, porosity and pore size distribution. The XRD pattern of POP-TB confirmed that the amorphous structure (Figure S1) The morphologies of POP-TB and HSO3-POP-TB were characterized by scanning electron (SEM). As shown in Fig. 3 A, the sulfonated HSO3-POP-TB retains a uniform spherical morphology. Compared to the pristine POP-TB, the particle volume of HSO3-POP-TB increased after sulfonation (Fig. 3 B). This expansion can be attributed to the swelling of the flexible POP-TB framework during the sulfonation process. The SEM images illustrate that despite the chemical modification, the overall structural integrity of the particles is preserved. The TEM images reveal a pronounced fingerprint region, indicating the lamellar stacking structure of the POP-TB material with abundant micro- and mesopores (Figure S2). The interlayer spacing is 0.48 nm, consistent with the pore size distribution data. This confirms that the microporosity primarily comes from interlayer stacking, while the mesoporosity arises from the cyclic formation due to monomer linkage. From the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves presented in Fig. 3 C and D, it is evident that the sulfonated HSO3-POP-TB maintains a similar profile to the original POP-TB. This similarity indicates that the structural framework of the material remains largely intact, even after undergoing harsh sulfonation treatment. Despite prolonged exposure to strong acid, the HSO3-POP-TB was still able to maintain a high specific surface area of 444 m²/g and substantial pore volume (Table S1). The FT-IR spectrum of HSO3-POP-TB, depicted in Fig. 3 E, reveals a notable absorption peak at 1186 cm−1, corresponding to the SO3 − groups, confirming their successful attachment to the POP-TB surface. Additionally, a decrease in the C-H stretching vibrations in the 2800–3200 cm−1 range is observed. This decrease suggests that the introduction of sulfonic acid groups partially disrupted the pristine POP-TB structure, likely contributing to the observed reduction in the specific surface area. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the sulfonated HSO3-POP-TB, as shown in Fig. 3 F, reveals significant weight loss between 40 and 100 °C. This weight loss is primarily due to the desorption of adsorbed water, indicating that the sulfonated material has a high capacity for water adsorption due to the presence of numerous sulfonic groups. Above 200°C, the material experiences considerable degradation, with the collapse of the framework structure leading to severe weight loss. This degradation suggests that the thermal stability of HSO3-POP-TB is compromised compared to the original POP-TB, and it limits the operational temperature for catalytic applications to below 200 °C. The elemental analysis results for POP-TB, shown in Table S2, indicate that it consists solely of C and H. The atomic ratio of C in POP-TB is found to be 1.36, which closely aligns with the theoretical C ratio of 1.35 expected for POP-TB synthesized from TRB and BB at a 1:2 molar ratio. This consistency suggests that the polymerization reaction between TRB and BB proceeded with the expected stoichiometry when the feed ratio was maintained at 1:2. For the sulfonated HSO3-POP-TB, the analysis revealed the presence of S at a concentration of 6.26 %. This corresponds to the incorporation of sulfonic acid groups (SO3H) into the polymer matrix. From this sulfur content, the amount of sulfonic acid groups in HSO3-POP-TB can be calculated to be approximately 2.0 mmol/g. This substantial incorporation of SO3H groups significantly enhances the material’s acidity and its potential as a catalyst. 3.3 Catalytic performances of HSO3-POP-TB in the dimerization of isopentene To ensure that the catalytic activity observed is due solely to the sulfonic acid groups, we conducted a control experiment using non-sulfonated POP-TB under the optimal reaction conditions. As expected, isopentene showed no conversion in the presence of POP-TB alone, confirming that the catalytic activity is entirely dependent on the presence of HSO3− groups. 3.3.1 Effect of catalyst loading The amount of catalyst significantly impacts the conversion of isopentene (C5) and the distribution of reaction products. We varied the catalyst loading from 40 to 90 mg at 70 °C ( Fig. 4 A). The results showed that increasing the catalyst amount from 40 to 70 mg led to a notable rise in C5 conversion from 44 % to 82 %. However, further increases in catalyst loading did not significantly enhance the conversion rate, while the selectivity for C10 decreased and the formation of cracking products increased. Therefore, the optimal catalyst loading was identified as 70 mg, balancing high C5 conversion with maximum C10 yield. 3.3.2 Effect of time To determine the optimal reaction time, we tested durations ranging from 3 to 7 h, using 70 mg of catalyst at 70 °C (Fig. 4 B). The C5 conversion exhibited a peak-like trend, increasing to a maximum at 5 h before declining. This decrease beyond 5 h is likely due to the decomposition of C10 into smaller molecules under the acidic conditions. Despite the variation in conversion rates, the selectivity for C10 remained above 90 % throughout the reaction, and the selectivity for C15 and cracking products were relatively stable. Thus, 5 h was chosen as the optimal reaction time to maintain high selectivity for C10 while avoiding excessive cracking. 3.3.3 Effect of temperature Reaction temperature is a crucial factor influencing both the conversion of isopentene and the product selectivity. After optimizing catalyst loading and reaction time, we explored the effects of different temperatures, ranging from 60 to 90 °C (Fig. 4 C). The C5 conversion increased rapidly from 18 % at 60 °C to 80 % at 70 °C. However, at 90 °C, although the C5 conversion did not improve significantly, the selectivity for C10 dropped sharply, and the selectivity for cracking products and long-chain C15 increased. This indicates that higher temperatures lead to further cracking or polymerization of C10 before it can desorb from the catalyst surface. Therefore, 70 °C was identified as the optimal temperature, providing a balance between high conversion and high C10 selectivity. 3.3.4 Effect of pressure The introduction of N2 pressure significantly impacts the catalytic dimerization of isopentene (C5), as evidenced by the marked decrease in C5 conversion and the decline in C10 selectivity shown in Fig. 4 D. The introduction of nitrogen gas dilutes the concentration of C5 components, leading to an increase in the average distance between C5 molecules and a significant reduction in molecular collision frequency. This suppresses the kinetic process of the polymerization reaction, ultimately resulting in a decrease in polymerization efficiency. 3.4 Stability study The stability of the HSO3-POP-TB catalyst in the oligomerization of isopentene was evaluated under the following conditions: 70 mg of catalyst, 2 mL of isopentene, a reaction temperature of 70 °C, and a reaction time of 5 h. The experimental setup and results are depicted in Fig. 5 . After each reaction, the catalyst was recovered by centrifugation and reused directly without any additional treatment. Over five consecutive runs, the C5 conversion rate exhibited only slight fluctuations with no significant decline, while the C10 selectivity remained largely consistent. This indicates that the HSO3-POP-TB catalyst maintains excellent stability during the dimerization of isopentene. Under these optimized conditions (70 °C, 5 h), the HSO3-POP-TB catalyst achieved a C5 conversion rate of 81.7 %, a C10 selectivity of 95.0 %, and a C10 yield of 77.6 %. These results highlight the robust performance and reusability of HSO3-POP-TB in the catalytic conversion of isopentene. More significantly, the catalyst was characterized by SEM and FT-IR after cyclic reactions. The SEM image (Figure S3) before and after the cyclic reactions, it was observed that there was no significant collapse in the framework structure of the catalyst. The FT-IR (Figure S4) results confirmed that the -HSO3 groups remained present after the reaction. 3.5 Comparison of catalytic performance The HSO3-POP-TB catalyst, obtained by treating POP-TB with HSO3Cl, exhibits a robust framework and a high density of strong acid sites. This catalyst was applied to the oligomerization of isopentene, and the effects of sulfonation temperature, sulfonation time, catalyst loading, temperature, time, and pressure were systematically studied. The optimization results identified 140 °C and 24 h as the optimal conditions or the sulfonation process. For the oligomerization reaction, the best operational parameters were found to be 70 °C, 5 h. Under optimized conditions, HSO3-POP-TB achieved a remarkable isopentene conversion rate, with a high selectivity for the dimer product (C10), surpassing the performance of traditional catalysts such as sulfonic acid resins, zeolites, and heteropoly acids. Table 1 provides a detailed comparison of the performance of HSO3-POP-TB with other catalysts under similar reaction conditions. HSO3-POP-TB demonstrated the highest isopentene conversion rate of 81.7 %, marginally surpassing DA-330 (80.9 %) and significantly higher than ITQ-1 (73.6 %), PW/MCM-41 (77.8 %), and Beta (77.0 %). The selectivity for the desired dimer product (C10) was notably high for HSO3-POP-TB at 95.0 %, compared to DA-330 (82.3 %), ITQ-1 (93.4 %), PW/MCM-41 (93.5 %), and Beta (90.2 %). The low selectivity for smaller oligomers (C6–9) and minimal formation of higher oligomers (C11–14 and C15) further highlight the effectiveness of HSO3-POP-TB. HSO3-POP-TB achieved the highest yield of C10 at 77.6 %, which is significantly better than DA-330 (66.6 %), ITQ-1 (68.7 %), PW/MCM-41 (72.7 %), and Beta (69.5 %). Moreover, HSO3-POP-TB demonstrated excellent stability and reusability. Even without any regeneration treatment, the catalyst maintained its high catalytic activity in subsequent reactions. This robust performance underlines the potential of HSO3-POP-TB as a superior catalyst for industrial applications in the efficient and selective conversion of light olefins. 3.6 Catalysis mechanism In this work, the feedstock isopentene is a mixture of 2-methyl-1-butene and 2-methyl-2-butene in a ratio of 1:9. The dimerization reaction of isopentene under solid acid catalysis follows a typical carbocation mechanism. This process can proceed via two primary reaction pathways, leading to different products, as illustrated in Fig. 6. First, in reactions (1) and (2), 2-methyl-1-butene and 2-methyl-2-butene react with hydrogen ions (H⁺) from the solution to form C5 carbocations (C5+). This step is crucial because the stability of the carbocation is essential for the subsequent reactions. Following the formation of the C5+, it reacts with another molecule of C5 olefin to produce C10 olefins. This carbocation-olefin reaction pathway is particularly effective under solid acid catalysis, facilitating the dimerization process. However, solid acid catalysts not only promote the formation of C10 olefins but also may lead to further oligomerization or cracking reactions, resulting in the formation of C15 olefins and other higher molecular weight cracking products. Studies indicate that the formation of stable carbocations and the presence of an alpha-position double bond are key factors in olefin oligomerization. The formation and stability of carbocations, especially those with alpha-position double bonds, determine the rate and selectivity of the reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, the sulfonated porous organic polymer HSO3-POP-TB, synthesized via Friedel-Crafts alkylation followed by sulfonation, has proven to be a highly efficient and stable catalyst for the dimerization of isopentene. Characterization of the catalyst revealed that HSO3-POP-TB maintains its structural integrity under optimal reaction temperatures, thereby demonstrating enhanced catalytic activity for isopentene dimerization compared to conventional sulfonated resins and zeolites. Process condition optimizations uncovered that at 70 °C and within a 5 h reaction duration, HSO3-POP-TB achieves an impressive isopentene conversion rate of 81.7 %, with a high selectivity towards C10 dimers at 95 %, translating to a substantial yield of 77.6 %. Notably, this HSO3-POP-TB catalyst retains excellent catalytic performance even after reuse without additional treatment. coredata.dc:description: The oligomerization of light olefins, such as isopentene, is crucial for producing valuable products like industrial chemicals in the petrochemical industry; however, developing efficient and stable catalysts remains challenging. In this study, we synthesized a sulfonated porous organic polymer, HSO3-POP-TB, via Friedel-Crafts alkylation using 1, 3, 5-triphenylbenzene (TB) and 4, 4’-dichloromethylbiphenyl (BB), followed by chlorosulfonic acid (HSO3Cl) sulfonation. The strong acidity and unique micro-/mesoporous structure of HSO₃-POP-TB are key to achieving high isopentene conversion and excellent dimer selectivity. Optimized HSO3-POP-TB demonstrated exceptional catalytic performance, with an isopentene conversion rate of 81.7 % and 95.0 % selectivity for the dimer product at 70 °C, surpassing conventional solid acid catalysts. Additionally, HSO3-POP-TB exhibited remarkable thermal stability and acid resistance, maintaining high activity over five reaction cycles without significant efficiency loss. These results highlight the potential of HSO3-POP-TB as a promising catalyst for the efficient and sustainable conversion of light olefins into valuable chemicals, addressing economic and environmental concerns.
